But now all's huſht, could wee finde time to pray,
They might find time to heare vs.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Shall wee be
Spectators of the royall inter-view
Betwixt the King and Queene?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Ten yeares diuorſt
Should challenge a kind meeting, let's obſerue
The forme and ſtate of this Court-complement,
(things I did neuer trade with:) Harke loud muſicke
Giues warning of their comming.

div.stage: Loud muſicke. Enter at one doore Agamemnon, Vlyſſes, Dio|med, Pyrhus, Menelaus: Synon and Therſites falling into their trayne. At the other Egiſtus, Clitemneſtra, Cethus, Oreſtes, Pylades, Hermione, Electra, &c.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Vnto our Country and our Houſhold-gods
Wee are at length return'd, trophied with honours,
With Troyes ſubuerſion and rich Aſiaes ſpoyles,
This is a ſacred day.

sp.speaker: Egiſt.
sp.l: Such Troy had once.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Vnto the gods wel'e ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: So Priam fell
Before the holy Altar.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: This Citty is not Troy.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Where Hellen treades,
I hold the place no better.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: See our Queene,
Orestes and Electra, for our ſake.
Princes of Greece daigne them your beſt ſalutes▪
Deare Clitemnestra.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Royall King and Husband.

div.stage: After their ſalute. All the rest complement as ſtrangers, but eſpecially Pyrhus and Oreſtes▪

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What's he that kneeles ſo cloſe vnto our Queen●

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Egiſtus and your ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hee was young
When we at firſt ſet ſayle from Aulis Gulfe,
Now growne from my remembrance: we ſhall ●●ude
Fit time to ſearch him further,

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Marke you that.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Yes, and it toucht me deepely.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Our ſiſter, and this young Hermione,
Daughter to vs aud Hellen.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Prity puppy.
Ofſuch a common brach.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Young Neoptolem●s,
This is the Lady promiſt you at Troy,
For your great ſeruice done there: ſhe's your owne,
Freely imbrace her then.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I ſee we are like
To haue a iolly kindred.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Pyrhus, inioy
Her whom I haue in contract?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Beauteous Lady,
The great'ſt ambition Pyrhus aymes at now,
Is how to know you farther.
Hath beene ſo mighty to reuenge the wrongs
Of my faire mother, can from Hermione
Challenge no leſſe then welcome.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Oh you gods,
Pyrhus, thou wert more ſafe inburning Troy
With horrour, fury blood, fires, foes about the●.
Then in my fathers court.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Another Collumne
On which to build my ſlaughters. Patience Prince,
This is no time for braues and Menaces,
I further ſhall inſtruct you.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: I haue done.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: See now the two Queenes meete, & ſmack in publick,
That oft haue ki●● in corners▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Ther●●tes?
Thou art growne a monſter, a ſtrange thing ſearſe knowns
'Mongſt ſouldiers, wiues and daughters.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: They are two ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Yes, and the two King-brothers royally
Betweene them two cornuted▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: We are to loud.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Princes of Greece, fi●ce we ha●e done a duty
To ſee our Generall mid▪ſt his people ſafe,
And after many dreadfull warres abroad
In peace at home. 'Tis fit we ſhould diſperſe
Vnto our ſeuerall Countries inſtantly,
I purpoſe for Aetolia, where my Queene
With longing waites my comming.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Not King Di●med,
Till you haue ſeene Me●ana's pompe and ſtat●
In amplieſt royalty expreſt at full,
Both taſted of our feaſts and Princely gifts.
The faire Aegiale, who hath ſo long
●orborne your preſence, will not I preſume
Deny to ſpare you to vs ſome few dayes,
To adde to the yeares number, though not as Generall
Yet will I lay on you a friends command▪
Which muſt not be deny'de.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Great Agamemnon
With mee was euer powerfull, I am his.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: And now faire ſiſter welcome back from Troy,
Be euer henceforth Spartaes.

sp.speaker: Hei.
sp.l: Your great care
In my enforced abſence (gracious Queene)
Expreſt vnto my deare Hermione,
Hath much obliged me to you. Oh my fate,
How ſwift time runnes: Oreſtes growne a man,
Whom I left in the Cradle ! Young Electra
Then (as I tak't) ſcarce borne, and now growne ripe,
Euen ready for an husband!

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: In whoſe abſence
If but one handſome ſweete-heart come in place,
Shee'l not turne tayle for't, if ſhee do● but take
After mine old Naunt Hellen.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The great and ſolemne preparation
Of the Court, ſtate and glory mighty Princes,
Attend for you within.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: All are conſecrated
Vnto your royall welcomes, enter then,
Wee'l feaſt like earthy gods, or god-like men▪

div.stage: Lo●d muſick. They poſſeſſe the Stage in all ſtate, ●●thus ſtayeth behind.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: My brayne about againe, for thou haſt found
New proiect now to worke on, and 'tis here,
Oreſtes hath receiu'd Hermione
From Clitemnestra's hand, her ſonle is his▪
And hee her Genius, two combind in one:
Yet ſhee is by the fathers Oath conferd
On Pyrhus, which ſhallbreede a ſtormy flawe
Ne're to be peec't againe, but by the deaths
Of the two hopefull youths: perhaps the hazard
Of all theſe Kings if my reuenge ſtrike home.
(Of that at leaſure) but the bloody ſtage
On which to act, Generall this night is thine,
Thou lyeſt downe mortall, who muſt riſe diuine.

div.stage: Enter Oreſtes to Cethus. Muſicke and healthing within.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Oh Cethus what's this muſicke vnto me,
That are compoſ'd of diſcords? what are healths
To him that is ſtrucke heart-ſicke? all thoſe ioyes
Whoſe leaders ſeeme to pierce againſt the roofes
Of theſe high ſtructures, to him that is ſtruct downe
Halfe way below the Center?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Were you lower,
Yet here's a hand can rayſe you, deeper caſt
Then to the loweſt Abiſme: It lyes in me
To aduance you to the height of happineſſe,
Where you ſhall liue eternil'd from the reach
Of any humane malice.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Hadſt thou ſeene
Her, in whoſe breaſt my heart was paradiſ'd,
Kiſt, courted, and imbrac'd.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: By Pyrhus.

sp.speaker: Oreſt▪
sp.l: Him:
What paſſionate and in●idiating lookes
Hee caſt on her, as if in ſcorne of me:
Shall hee inioy my birth-right, or inheri●e
Where I am heire apparant? ſhall he vſurpe▪
Or pleade my intereſt, where I am poſſeſt?
Rule where I raigne? where I am ſtated, ſit?
Braue me in my peculiar Soueraignty?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Hee muſt not, ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Show mee to depoſe.
The proud Vſurper then.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Prince, make't my charge.
In the meane time, from your diſtracted from
Exile all diſcontent, let not leaſt ra●e
Raigne in your eye, or harſhne●●e in your tongue,
Smooth waters are ſtill deep'ſt▪ wa●te on the King,
And be no ſtranger to your mothers eye,
Or forraigne to your Kindred: the feaſt ſpent,
And night with it: the morrow ſhall beget
Proiect of more import (ſcarſe thought on now.)

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: I build vpon thy Counſell.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Which hath proou'd,
Fixt as a rocke, ſtill conſtant, and vnmoou'd.

sp.speaker: Egiſt.
sp.l: What ●ethus here? why no ſuch matter now
No cauſe of feare, or leaſt ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Tuſh, preſume it, we are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Obſerue it, they are ſtill ſecureſt, whom
The Diuell driues to ruine.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Harke, their healths
Carrowſing to the Generals Victories,
In all thy heate of ioy, and fire of wine,
No ſparke of iealouſly, all th' Argument
Of their diſcourſe, what they haue done at Troy.
Still health on health, and the great Generall
So farre from ſeeming to haue leaſt diſtaſte,
That in all affable tearmes hee courts his Queene,
Nay more, cuts off all banquet Ceremonies,
To haſten his bed-pleaſures, as if times diſtance
Betwixt his boord and pallade, ſeemed more tedious
Then all his Ten yeares ſiege.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Goe, loſt man,
Sinke on firme ground, be ſhipwrackt in a Calme.
Theſe healthes are to your ruines, his reuenge:
Hath not Egistus read of a diſeaſe
Where men dye laughing: others that haue drunke
Poyſon in ſteed of Cordials, periſh ſo?
To dye tis nothing, ſince tis all men due:
But wretchedly to ſuffer, fall vnpittied,
Vnpittied? nay derided, moekt, and curſt:
To dye as a baſe Traytor, and a Thiefe,
The adulterator of his Soueraignes bed,
The poyſon of the Atred●● family,
And ſcandall of his iſſue, ſo to dye?

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Egistus will preuent, he by this hand
Muſt fal, 'fore whom all Aſia could not ſtand.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: The banquet is broke vp, ſleep cals to reſt,
And mid-nights houre for murther, ſtill ſhowes beſt▪

div.stage: Loud muſicke. Enter Egiſtus with his ſword drawne, hi|deth himſelfe in the chamber behind the Bed-curtaines: all the Kings come next in, conducting the Generall and his Queene to their Lodging, and after ſome complement leaue them, enery one with torches vſhered to their ſeuerall chambers, &c.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Methinkes this night, we Clitemneſtra meete,
At a new bridall; all Attendants leaue vs,
Wee now are onely for bed-priuacies.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Great ſir, I that ſo long haue bin your widdow,
Will be this night your hand-mayde.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: You told me, Queene,
Oreſtes was a cunning horſe-man growne:
It pleaſde me much to heare it.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Greece reports
No Centare can ride better▪

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: And young Electra,
In all th' indowments that may beſt become
A Princeſſe of her breeding, moſt compleate.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: It was in your long abſence, all my care,
(Being my charge) that you at your returne
Might finde them to your wiſhes,

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Thankes for that.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: How cunningly he ſeemes to carry it▪
But we muſt finde preuention.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Who's without there?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Why ſtarted you?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Not all the Aſian Legions, no not Hector
Arm'd with his bals of wild-fire, had the power
To ſhake me like this tremor: Is our Pallace
Leſſe ſafe in Greece, amidſt our ſubiects here,
Then were our Tents in Aſia?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Where, if not here in Clitemnestraes armes,
Can ſafety dwell?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: And faire Queene, it ſhould bee ſo.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: But why ſir caſt you ſuch ſuſpicious eyes
About your Chamber? are wee not alone?
Or will you to the priuate ſweetes of night,
Call tell tale witneſſe?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Now tis gone agayne. Shall we to reſt?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: So pleaſe you royall Sir.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: How hard this Doune feeles, like a monument
Cut out of marble. Beds reſemble Graues,
And theſe me-thinkes appeare like winding ſheets,
Prepar'd for corſes.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Oh how ominouſly
Doe you preſage: you much affright me ſir
In this our long-wiſht meeting.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: All's ſhooke off.
I now am arm'd for pleaſure: you commended
Late one Egiſtus to me, prithee Queene
Of what condition is he?

div.stage: They both wound him, at which there is a greate thunder crack.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Tyrant this.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: And I am thus his ſecond.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Treaſon, murder, Treaſon:
This ſhowes, we Princes are no more then men.
Thankes Iou● tis fit when Monarches fall by Treaſon,
Thunder to al● the world, would ſhow ſome reaſon.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: The deede is done, lets flye to ſome ſtrong Cittadell,
For our more ſafety.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Hee thus made diuine:
Now my Egiſtus, I am ſoly thine.

div.stage: Anoyſe of vproare within. Enter all the Kings with other Seruants halfe vnready, as newly started from their Beds. Oreſtes, Hermione, Pillades, Electra, &c.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What ſtrange tumultuous noyſe is this ſo late▪
To rouſe vs from our beds?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Prodigious ſure,
Sin●● 'tis confirm'd by Thunder.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: In mine eares
Did neuer ſound ſeeme halfe to terrible.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Nor to your eyes, as this ſad obiect is,
See great Atrides groueling.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What damn'd Villaine
Was auther of this proiect?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Horrid ſight.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Reſt you amazed all, as thunder ſtruke,
And without ſence or motion Apoplext,
And onely heare me ſpeake: Orestes, he
Who as if marbled by Meduſaes head,
Hath not one teare to fall, or ſigh to ſpend,
Till I finde out the murderer, and on him
Inflict remarkable vengance: for I vowe
Were it my father, brother, or his Queene,
Hadſt thou my weeping ſiſter hand in it.
If hee? whom equall, (if not rankt aboue)
I euer did, and ſhall loue Pylades?
Wert ſhe whoſe wombe did beare me, where I l●y
Full nine moneths bedded ere I ſaw the Sunne,
Or the moſt abiect Traytor vnder Heauen,
Their doomes were all alike, and this I vowe.
Now you whom this ſilent and ſpeechleſſe King
Hath oft commanded, this now ſenceleſſe braine
As oft directed, this now ſtrengthleſſe hand
More oft protected in a warre, that ſhall
Be to all times example: Lend your ſhoulders
To beare him, who hath kept you all in life,
This is a blacke and mourning funerall right,
Deedes of this nature muſt be throughly ſearcht,
Nay be reueng'd: the gods haue ſayd tis good,
The morning Sunne ſhall riſe and bl●ſh in blood.

div.stage: They beare him off with a ſad and funerall march, &c.

div.head: Actus Quintus: Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Pyrhus, Hermione, Therſites, and Synon.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sweete Lady, can you loue:

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Forbeare my Lord,
Can ſuch a thing as loue be once nam'd here,
Where euery Marble that ſupports this roofe,
In emulation doth vye teares with vs?
Nay where the wounds of ſuch a mighty King
Haue yet ſcarſe bled their laſt.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Tuſh faire Hermione,
Theſe ſights that ſeeme to Iadies terrible,
Are common to vs ſouldiers; when from field returning
All ſmear'd in blood, where Dukes and Kings li● ſlaine,
Yet in our Tents at mid-night it frights not vs
From courting a ſweete Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Hee ſayth right,
And note of this how I can poetiſe:
This his great father of his Loue deſir'd.
When from the ſlaughter of his foes retyr'd
Hee doft his Cuſhes and vnarm'd his head,
To tumble with her on a ſoft day bed:
It did reioyce Briſoi● to imbrace
His bruiſed armes, and kiſſe his blood-ſtain'd face.
Theſe hands which he ſo often did imbrew
In blood of warlike Troians whom hee ſlew,
Were then imploy'd to tickle, touch and feele,
And ſhake a Lance that had no print of ſteele.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Continue in that ve●●e, I'le feed thy Muſe
With Crafi●h, Praunes and Lobſters.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You brought theſe of purpoſe to abuſe m●e.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Peace Therſites,
And Synon you no more.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Wee ſee by Agamemnon all are mortall,
And I but ſhew his neece Hermione
The way of all fleſh.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Tis an eaſie path,
(The Mother and the Aunt haue troad it both)
If ſhee haue wit to follow.

div.stage: Enter Vlyſſes, Menelaus, Diomed with others.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: If it beſo, Egiſtus is a traytor,
And ſhee no more our ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Vlyſ.
sp.l: Tis not poſſible
A Queene of her high birth and parentage
Should haue ſuch baſe hand in her husbands death,
Her husband and her ſoueraigne.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Double treaſon,
Could it be proou'd againſt her.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It appeares
So farre againſt humanity and nature
We dare not once ſuſpect it, but till proofe
Explaine it further, hold it in ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Vlyſ.
sp.l: Oh but their ſuddaine flight and fortifying.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Theſe are indeed preſumptions, but leaue that
To a moſt ſtrict inquiry euen for reuerence
Of Maieſty and Honour to all Queenes,
For loue of vs becauſe ſhee was our ſiſter,
Both for Orestes and Electra's ſake
Whoſe births are branded in ſo foule a deede
Till wee examine further circumſtances
Spare your ſeuerer cenſures.

sp.speaker: Vliſ.
sp.l: Tis a buſineſſe
That leaſt concernes vs, but for Honours ſake
And that hee was our Generall.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What, prince ly Pyrhus courting our faire daughter?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Yes ſir, but in a time vnſeaſonable
Euen as the ſuite it ſelfe is.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: All delayes
Shall be cut off and ſhe be ſwayd by vs.
Theſe Royall Princes ere they leaue Mycone,
Shall ſee theſe ●uptiall rights ſolemnized,
Weele keepe our faith with Pyrhus.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Wee our vowes
As conſtant to the bright Hermione.
Firſt ſee the royall Generall here interr'd
And buried like a ſouldier, 'tis his due:
To queſtion of his death concernes not vs,
Wee leaue it to Heauens iuſtice and reuenge.
The rights perform'd with faire Hermione,
Then to our ſeuerall Countries each man poſt,
Captaines diſperſe ſtill when the General's loſt.

div.stage: Enter Cethus, Oreſtes, and Pylades. diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Egistus? and our Mother?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Am I Cethus,
Are you Orestes, and this Pyllades,
So ſure they were his murderers: this diſguiſe
Will ſuite an act of death, full to the life
Hee ſtands vpon a ſtrict and ſecure guard,
I haue plotted your admittance, it will take
Doubt not, it cannot fayle, I haue caſt it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: As ſent from Menelaus?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Whoſe name elſe
Can breake through ſuch ſtrong guards, where feare and guilt
Keepe hourely watch?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: It is enough, I haue't,
And thou the faithful'ſt of all friends deare Pillades,
Doe but aſſiſt mee in my vowed reuenge
And inioy faire Electra.

sp.speaker: Pyl.
sp.l: Next your friendſhip
It is the priſe ●ayme at, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What ſlip you time and opportunity,
Or looke you after dreames?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: I am a wake.
And to ſend them to their eternall ſleepe.
In expedition there is ſtill ſucceſſe,
In all delayes defect: the traytor dyes
Were hee in league with all the deſtinies.
And tis a fruitfull yeare for villany,
And I a thrining Farmer. In this interim
I haue more plots on foote: King Menelaus:
I haue incenc'd againſt proud Diom●d▪
Fyrhus againſt Orestes, hee 'gainſt him,
Ʋlyſſes without parralell for wit
Againſt them all: ſo that the firſt combuſtion
Shall burne them vp to aſhes. Oh Palamides,
So deare was both thy loue and memory,
Not Hellen by her whoredome caus'd more blood
Streaming from Princes breſts, then Cethus ſhall
(Brother) for thine vntimely funerall.

div.stage: Enter Egiſtus, Clitemneſtra with a ſtrong guard.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Let none preſume to dare into our preſence
Or paſſe our guard, but ſuch well knowne to vs and to our Queene.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: The charge hath paſt vs round▪

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: When ſinnes of ſuch hye nature 'gainſt vs riſe,
Tis fit wee ſhould be kept with heedfull eyes.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Preſume it my Egistus, we are ſafe,
The Fort wherein we liue impregnable:
Or ſay we were ſurpris'd by ſtratagem,
Or ſhould expoſe our liues vnto the cenſure
Of Law and Iuſtice, euen in theſe extreames
There were not the leaſt feare of difficulty.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Your reaſon Madam.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Whom doth this concerne
But our owne blood? ſhould Pyrhus grow inrag'd▪
I haue at hand my neece Hermione
To calme his fury: what doth this belong to
Vlyſſes, or Aetolian Diomed?
Are they not ſtrangers? If it come in queſtion
By Menelaus, is hee not our brother▪
Our ſiſter Hellen in his boſome ſleepes,
And can with him doe all things, feare not then,
Wee are euery way ſecure.

sp.speaker: Egiſt.
sp.l: Oh but Oreſtes
His ey's to mee like lightning, and his arme
Vp heau'd thus, ſhewes like Iones thunder-bolt
Aym'd againſt luſt and murder.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Hee's our ſonne,
The filiall duty that's hereditary
Vnto a mothers name preuents theſe feares:
Electra's young, and childiſh Pilades
Swai'd by his friend: It reſts, could we but worke
Hellen and Menelaus to our faction,
Egistus ſhould be ſtated in Mycene,
Wee liue his Queene and bride.

sp.speaker: Egiſt.
sp.l: Feare's ſtill ſuſpicious.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: A Letter ſir.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Tis ſuperſcrib'd from the great Spartae's King,
And the Queene Hellen.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Who the meſſenger?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Two Gentlemen who much importune you
For ſpeedy anſwer.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Bidde them waite without,
Now fates proue but propitious, then my kingdome
I ſhall preſume eſtabliſh't.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: There's no feare,
Orestes once remoou'd, and that's my charge
Either by ſword or poyſon.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: See faire Queene,
Reade what your brother writes, by this we are
Eternis'd in our happineſſe, and our liues
Rooted in ſweete ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Wee not ſuſpect you in our brothers death,
A deede too baſe for any Noble breſt.
Therefore in this neceſſity of ſtate,
And knowing in this forced vacancy
So great a kingdome cannot want a guide:
The ſoueraignty we thought good to conferre
On Clitemnestra, or whatſubſtiture
Shee in her beſt diſcretion ſhall thinke fit,
The vnited Kings of Greece●aue thus decre●d.
Your brother Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: We are happied euer.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: A ioy ratified▪
And ſubiect to no change.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Call in the meſſengers,
Oreſtes and Electra once remoon'd,
Wee haue no riuall, no competitor,
Therefore no iealouſie at all.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: None, none.
The gods haue with theſe Kings of Greece agreed
In his ſupplanting and inſtating thee,
Thee my moſt deare Egistus.

div.stage: Oreſtes and Pyllades diſguiſed are conducted in.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: You the men?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Thoſe, whom the Spartan King made ſpeciall choice of
To truſt this great affaire with.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: And y'are welcome,
But are you men of action: ſuch I meane,
As haue beene Souldiers bred, whoſe eyes inur'd
To ſlaughter and combuſtions: at the like
Would not change face, or tremble?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: They that to ſee
Legges, armes, and heads ſtrowed on Scamander Plaine,
Kings by the common ſouldiers ſtew'd in goare,
And three parts hid with their imboweld Steedes,
Shadowing their mangled bodies from the Sunne,
As if aboue the earth to bury them:
They that to ſee an Aſian Potentate
Kil'd at the holy Altar, his owne blood
Mixt with his ſonnes and daughters, Towers demoliſht
Cruſhing whole thouſands, of each ſexe and age
Beneath their ruines: and theſe horrid ſights
Lighted by ſcathe- fires, they that haue beheld
Theſe and more dreadfull obiects; can their eyes
Moue at a private ſlaughter?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Y'are for vs,
Will you for hire, for fauour, or aduancement,
(Now warres are done) to be made great in Court,
And vndertake that one man eaſily ſpar'd
Amongſt ſo many millions (now ſuruiuing)
That ſuch a creature, no way neceſſary
But a meere burden to the world wee liue in,
Hee might no longer liue?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: But name the man,
And as I loue Egiſtus, honour you
And al that glory in ſuch noble deeds.
Be what hee will; hee's loſt.

sp.speaker: Egiſt.
sp.l: Orestes, then?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Is there none then the world ſo well may ſpare
As young Oreſtes? Hee to doe't?

div.stage: Hee kils Egiſtus, firſt diſcouering himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Egiſt.
sp.l: Vaine world farewell,
My hopes withall, no building long hath ſtood
Whoſe ſleight foundation hath bin layd in blood.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: I'le dye vpon his boſome.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Secure the Fort my deare friend Pillades,
And to your vtmoſt pacifie the guard:
Tell them we are Orestes and their Prince,
And what wee did was to reuenge the death
Of their dead Lord and Soueraig●e▪

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Sir i'le doe't.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Oh mee, that thinking to haue catcht at Heauen,
Am plung'd into an hell of miſery.
Egistus dead? what comfort can I haue,
One foote Inthron'd, the tother in the graue.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Can you finde teares for ſuch an abiect Groome,
That had not for an husband one to ſhed?
Oh monſtrous, monſtrous woman ● is this carrion,
Is this dead Dog, (Dog ſaid I?) nay what's worſe,
Worthy the ſigh or mourning of a Queene,
When a King lies vnpittied?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Thou a ſonne?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: The name I am aſham'd of: oh Agamemnon,
How ſacred is thy name and memory!
Whoſe acts ſhall fill all forraigne Chronicles
With admiration, and moſt happy hee
That can with greateſt Art but booke thy deeds:
Yet whilſt this rottenneſſe, this gangreen'd fleſh
Whoſe carkas is as odious as his name
Shall ſtinking lie, able to breede a Peſt,
Hee with a Princeſſe teares to be imbalm'd,
And a King lie neglected?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Baſtard.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: If I be,
Damn'd be the whore my Mother, I, I am ſure
Nor my dead father had no hand in i●.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Oh that I could but lengthen out my yeares
Onely to ſpend in ●urſes.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Vpon whom?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: On whom but thee for my Egistus death?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: And I could wiſh my ſelfe a Neſtur● age
To curſe both him and thee for my dead father.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Doeſt thou accuſe mee for thy fathers death?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Indeede 'twould ill become me being a ſonne,
But were I ſure it were ſo, then I durſt;
Nay, more then that, reuenge it.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Vpon mee?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Were all the mothers of the earth in one,
All Empreſſes and Queenes caſt in one mould,
And I vnto that one a onely ſonne,
My ſword ſhould rauiſh that inceſtuous breast
Of nature, and of ſtate▪

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: I am as innocent of that blacke deede,
As was this guiltleſſe Gentleman here dead.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Oh all you powers of Heauen I inuocate,
And if you will not heare me, let Hell do't:
Giue me ſome ſig●e from eyther feinds or angell,
I call you both as te●tates.
sp.stage: Enter the Ghost of Agamemnon, poynting vnto his wounds: and then to Egiſtus and the Queene, who were his murderers, which done, hee vaniſheth.
sp.l: Godlike ſhape,
Haue you (my father) left the Elizium fieldes,
Where all the ancient Heroes line in bliſſe,
To bring your ſelfe that ſacred teſtimony,
To crowne my approbation: Lady ſee.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: See what? thy former murder makes thee mad,

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Reſt Ghoſt in peace, I now am ſatisfied,
And neede no further witneſſe: ſaw you nothing?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: What ſhould I ſee ſaue this ſad ſpectacle,
Which blood-ſhootes both mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: And nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Mine eyes are clearer ſighted then, and ſee
Into thy boſome. Murdreſſe.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Inceſtuous ſtrumpet, whoſe adulteries,
When Treaſon could not hide, thou thoughts to couer,
With moſt inhumane murder.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Meaning vs?

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Then, monſter, thou didſt firſt inſtruct mine hand,
How to write blood, when being a Wife and Queene,
Thou kildſt a King and husband, and haſt taught
Mee being a ſonne, how to deſtroy a mother.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Oh moſt vnnaturall.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: That I learnt of thee.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Vnheard of cruelty, but heauens are ●uſt.
And all remarkeable ſinnes puniſh with marke,
One miſchiefe ſtill another doth beger,
Adultery murder: I am loſt, vndone.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Being no wife, Orestes is no ſonne.

div.stage: Enter Cethus and Pillades with the guard.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The guard all ſtand for you, acknowledging
Orestes Prince and King.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: I now am neither.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What obiect's this? Queene Clitemnestra ſ●aine?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I hope no ſonnes hand in't

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Orestes did it,
The other title's loſt.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: All my plots take
Seyond my apprehe●ſion.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: This is an age
Of nothing but portents and prodigies.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: The fathers hand as deepe was in her death
As was the ſonnes, hee pointed, and I ſtrooke:
Was hee not then as vnkind to a Wife,
As I was to a Mother?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Oh my friend,
What haue you done?

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: There is a Plaſma, or deepe pit
Iuſt in the Center fixt for Parricides,
I'l keepe my Court there, and Erinnis, ſhee
In ſtead of Hebe, ſhall attend my Cup,
Charon the Ferri-man of Hell ſhall bee
My Ganimed.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The Prince is ſure diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: New proiect ſtill for me.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: I'le haue a guard of Furies which ſhall light mee
Vnto my nuptiall bed with funerall Teades,
The ●atall ſiſters ſhall my hand-maides b●e,
And waite vpon the faire Hermione.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Hermione? ſhee is betroth'd to Pyrhus,
And (mourning for your abſence) all the way
Vnto the Temple ſhee will ſtrowe with teares.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Ha? Pyrhus rape my deare Hermione?
Hee that ſhall dare to interpoſe my purpoſe▪
Or croſſe mee in mine Hymineall rights,
I'le make him lie as flat on the cold earth
As doth this hound Egiſtus.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: And I would ſo.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Would? ●ay I will, his father woare a ſmocks,
And in that ſhape rap't Deiadamia.
Hee ſhall not vſe my Loueſo, oh my Mother;
Friend take that obiect hence.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: But you Hermione,

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: My hand's yet deepe in blood, but to the wriſt,
It ſhall ſhall be to the elbowe: gods, nor men,
Angels, nor Furies ſhall my rage withſtand,
Not the graue Honour of th' aſſembled Kings,
Not Reuerence of the Altar, nor the Prieſt:
No ſuperſtition ſhall my fury ſlay▪
Till Pyrhus from the earth be ſwept away,

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Pillades attend your friend.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Hee's all my charge,
My life and his are twinnes.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Their mines are countermin'd, Cethus, thy fall
Is either plotted, or to blowe vp all.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: My head akes brother.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What a batchiler,
And troubled with the Spartan Kings diſeaſe?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: No, there's a wedding breeding in my braine,
Pyrhus the Bride-groome: thou ſtrange creature woman▪
To what may I compare thee?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Canſt thou deuiſe ought bad inough?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Tis ſayd they looke like Angels, and of light▪
But for the moſt part, ſuch light Angels prooue,
Ten hundred thouſand of their honeſties
Will ſcarce weigh eleauen Dragmaes.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Clite●neſtra,
And Hellen for example.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Young Hermi●ne
Hath face from both.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: The ſharpe ſhrewes noſe, they hate hereditary.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Therſites, I commend that fellowes wit
Proffred a wife young, beautifull and rich,
Onely one fault ſhe had, ſhe wanted braine:
Who anſwered in a creature of that ſexe,
I nere deſire more wiſedome; then to know
Her husbands bed from anothers.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I commend him,
But tis not in th' Atrides family,
To finde out ſuch a woman.

div.stage: An Altar ſet fo●rth, Enter Pyrhus Lending Hermione as a bride, Menelaus, Vliſſes, Diomed. A great trayne, Pyrhus and Hermione kneele at the altar.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: See now the ſacred nuptiall rights proceede▪
The Prieſts prepare the Alter.

sp.speaker: Fyr.
sp.l: Hymen to whom my vowes I conſecrate
As all my loue. To thee Hermione,
Whom in the preſence of theſe Argiue Kings,
I heare contract, be thou auſpitious to vs:
This flamming ſubſtitute to Saturnes ſonne,
Within whoſe ſacred Temple wee are rooft▪
And before all theſe high Celeſtiall gods
And goddeſſes, in whoſe eyes now we kneele:
Eſpecially you I●n● Queene of marriage,
And faire Lucina, who haue child-births charge,
Your fauours I inuoake: Let your chaſt fires
Drye vp this Virgins teares; make her ſo fruitefull
That in her iſſue great Achilles name
And fame withall, may liue eternally▪
Proceede Prieſt to your other Ceremonies▪

div.stage: Enter Oreſtes, Cethes, and Pilades, with the guard, all their weapons drawne, Oreſtes〈◊〉〈◊〉Pyrhus.

sp.speaker: Oreſt.
sp.l: Priam before the holy Alter fell,
Before the Alter bid thy life farwell:
Reſcue Hermione.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Achilles ſonne
Cannot reuengeleſſe dye, then witneſſe all,
Blood muſt flow high where ſuch great Princes fal.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Oreſtes is in danger.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Saue Prince Pyrhus.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: This plot was layd
Both for your life and Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Menelaus: ſhall neuer beare it ſo.

sp.speaker: Vlyſ.
sp.l: Fy Therſites,
Thy ſword againſt me.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Curſe vpon all whoores.

div.stage: A confuſed ſcuffle, in which Oreſtes kils Pyrhus: Pyrhus, Oreſtes: Cethus wounds Pillades, Diomed, Menelaus, Vliſſes, Therſites, &c. All fall dead ſane Vliſſes, who beareth thence Hermione: which done, Cethus riſeth vp from the dead bodies and ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What all aſleepe? and are theſe goſſiping tongues,
That boaſted nought faue Warre and Victory,
Now mute and ſilent? Oh thou vgly rogue,
Where's now thy rayling? and thou parracide,
Thy madneſſe is now tam'd, thou need'ſt no chaines
To bring thee to thy wits, darkneſſe hath don't.
This Diomed? who dar'd to encounter Mars,
And ſayd to wound faire Ʋenus in the hand:
Where's your valour now? Aegiale,
Vnleſſe (as ſome ſay) ſhe be better ſtor'd,
Is like to lye without a bed-fellow:
Riſe Pillades, and helpe to awake thy friend,
What doth your friendſhip ſleepe now? Menelaus
Hellen's with a new ſweete-heart ith'next roome,
Wilt thou be ſtill a Cuckold? winke at errors
As pandors do and wittoles? Cethus now
Be crown'd in Hyſtory for a reuenge,
Which in the former World wants preſident:
Methinks, as when the Giants warr'd'gainſt heauen,
And dar'd for primacy with Ioue himſelfe▪
Hee darting 'gainſt their mountaines thunder-boles▪
Which ſhattred them to peeces: the warre done,
I like the great Olimpicke Iupiter,
Walke ore my ruines, tread vpon my ſpoyles
With maieſty, I pace vpon this floore
Pan'd with the trunkes of Kings and Potentates,
For what leſle could haue ſated my reuenge?
This arch-rogue falne amongſt them? he whoſe eie●
Had the prepoſterous vertue to fire Troy.
Now is thy blacke ſoule for thy periuries
Swimming in red damnation.

div.stage: Synon who had before counterfeited death, riſeth vp, and anſwereth.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Sir, not yet,
All pollicies liue not in Cethus brayne,
Synon hath ſhare, and know if thou haſt craft,
I haue reſeru'd ſome cunning: ſee my body
Free and vntoucht from wounds.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Speake, ſhall we then
Diuide theſe dead betwix● vs, and both liue?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: If two Sunnes cannot ſhine within one ſpheare,
Then why ſhould two arch-villaines? thou haſt diſcouered
Projects almoſt beyond me, and for which
I haue ingroſt a mortall enuy here,
I will be ſole, or none.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Ceaſe then to be,
That I may liue without Competitor.
Cauſe Synons name be rae'd out of the World,
And onely mine remembred.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Thine's but frailty,
My ●ame ſhall be immortall; made more glorious
In treading vpon thee, as thou on theſe;
●●oope thou my Vnderling.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: I ſtill ſhall ſtand
sp.stage: They fight, and kill one another.
sp.l: Rooted.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: And yet cut downe by Synons hand.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: I now am duſt like theſe.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: One ſingle fight
Ends him, who millions ruin'd in one night.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Can you behold this ſlaughter?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Yes, and dye
Atſight of it: for why ſhould Hellen liue▪
Hellen the cauſe of all theſe Princes deaths▪
Ceaſe to lament, reach me my Glaſſe Hermione,
Sweete Orphant do; thy fathers dead already,
Nor will the fates lend thee a mother long.
sp.stage: Enter Hermione with a looking glaſſe, then exit.
sp.l: Thankes, and ſo leaue me. Was this wrinkled fore-head
When 'twas at beſt, worth halfe ſo many liues?
Where is that beauty? liues it in this face
Which hath ſet two parts of the World at warre,
Beene ruine of the Aſian Monarchy,
And almoſt this of Europe? this the beauty
That launch'd a thouſand ſhips from Aulis gulfe?
In ſuch a poore repurchaſe, now decayde?
See fayre ones, what a little Time can doe;
Who that conſiders when a ſeede is ſowne,
How long it is ere it appeare from th'earth,
Then ere it ſtalke, and after ere it blade,
Next ere it ſpread in leaues, then bud, then flower:
What care in watring, and in weeding tooke,
Yet crop it to our vſe: the beauties done,
And ſmel: they ſcarſe laſt betwixt Sunne and Sunne▪
Then why ſhould theſe my blaſtings ſtill ſuruiue,
Such royall ruines: or I longer liue,
Then to be termed Hellen the beautifull.
I am growne old, and Death is ages due,
When Courtiers ſooth, our glaſſes will tell true.
My beauty made me pittied, and ſtill lou'd,
But that decay'd, the worlds aſſured hate
Is all my dowre, then Hellen yeeld to fate▪
Here's that, my ſoule and body muſt diuide,
The guerdon of Adultery, Luſt, and Pride.

sp.speaker: Vlyſ.
sp.l: In thee they are puniſh t: of all theſe Princes,
And infinite numbers that oppoſed Troy,
And came in Hellens quarrell (ſaue my ſelfe).
Not one ſuruies, (thankes to the immortall powers)
And I am purpoſde now to acquire by Sea,
My Kingdome and my deare Penelope,
And ſince I am the man ſoly reſeru'd,
Accept me for the Authors Epilogue.
If hee haue beene two bloody? tis the Story,
Truth claimes excuſe, and ſeekes no farther glory,
Or if you thinke he hath done your patience wrong
(In teadious Sceanes) by keeping you ſo long,
Much matter in few words, hee bad me ſay
Are hard to expreſſe, that lengthned out his Play.

body.trailer: Here ends the whole Hiſtory of the destruction of Troy.
